discussion.content:
D. variance
EIGRP can balance traffic across multiple routes that have different metrics, which is called unequal-cost load balancing. The degree to which EIGRP performs load balancing is controlled with the variance command.

questions.question_text: Which configuration command is used to enable EIGRP unequal-cost path load balancing?
If the primary path goes down, what will EIGRP use to reach a destination?
questions.answer_description: The key to this question is the four terminology about DUAL. Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP) is an enhanced distance-vector protocol based on the diffusing update algorithm (DUAL). It is capable of (conservatively) finding all loop-free paths to any given destination based on route advertisements from neighbors. The neighbor (or neighbors) with the best path to a destination is called the successor. The remaining neighbors with loop-free paths to the destination are called feasible successors. To reduce traffic load on the network, EIGRP maintains neighbor relationships and exchanges routing information only as needed, using a query process to find alternate paths when all loop-free paths to a destination have failed.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the output.
//IMG//

What IOS command produces this output?

Select the best response -

questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
The ASBR accepts RFC 1918 addresses and set these networks to tag 255 but when advertising into Area 0, the ABR Area 0 filters out these networks because they match tag 255 so the OSPF backbone will not learn any RFC 1918 addresses.
Note that if you use an ACL in a route-map deny clause, routes that are permitted by the ACL are not redistributed.
All the networks with tag 255 are blocked by the clause 10 while all other networks are permitted by the clause 20 of the route-map (if a match command is not present, all routes match the clause).
Note:
RFC 1918 addresses include:
+ Class A: 10.0.0.0 10.255.255.255 (10/8 prefix)
+ Class B: 172.16.0.0 172.31.255.255 (172.16/12 prefix) + Class C: 192.168.0.0 192.168.255.255 (192.168/16 prefix)

discussion.content:
C. The OSPF backbone will not learn any RFC 1918 addresses. 
Well described as an Explanation.

comments.content:
Nemanja is right
C. The OSPF backbone will not learn any RFC 1918 addresses.

discussion.content: B. LSA Type 5s will not be received by the ABR from the ASBR.

questions.answer_ET: D. The matched prefix-list addresses will be given a metric of 255, which is essentially unreachable.
questions.answer: D. The matched prefix-list addresses will be given a metric of 255, which is essentially unreachable.

choices.B: LSA Type 5s will not be received by the ABR from the ASBR.
choices.A: The ASBR route-maps are basically useless, because there are no deny prefix-lists.
choices.C: The OSPF backbone will not learn any RFC 1918 addresses.
